title.narrative: Liberian Swedish Feeder Roads Project, phase 3
Liberian Swedish Feeder Roads Project, phase 3

description.narrative:
English text The Ministry of Public Works (MPW) has applied from the embassy of Sweden in Monrovia, for funding of 202 million SEK to carry out the “Liberia Swedish Feeder Road Project (LSFRP) 3” in Liberia during the period 2017-2021.
The intervention aims at improving opportunities for poor people to enhance their living conditions and livelihoods by the provision of sustainable road access by (a) enabling small-scale farmers to market more agricultural produce; (b) facilitating all year round social service delivery particularly in the health and education sectors and (c) creating of income earning opportunities for young men and women in the rural areas. The Feeder Road Unit (FRU) at the MPW will implement the intervention assisted by a well-established consulting firm.
The intervention’s total budget is about 280 million SEK, out of which Liberia’s own funding from the Road Fund is approximately 78 million SEK.

Vägministeriet i Liberia (Ministry of Public Works, MPW) har sökt finansiering från Sida, med beloppet 197 miljoner SEK för att genomföra projektet ”Liberia Swedish Feeder Road Project (LSFRP) 3” i Liberia under perioden 2017-2021.
Insatsen syftar till att förbättra möjligheterna för fattiga människor att förbättra sina levnadsvillkor och inkomster genom att bygga landsbygdsvägar som (a) gör det möjligt för småskaliga bönder att marknadsföra sina jordbruksprodukter; (b) underlätta leverans av sociala tjänster särskilt inom hälso- och utbildningssektorerna och (c) att skapa inkomstmöjligheter för unga män och kvinnor på landsbygden. Som en del av insatsen ingår en upphandlad internationell projektimplementering konsult (TA). Enheten för landsbygdsvägar (FRU) på MPW kommer att genomföra projektet med stöd av TA konsulten. Enligt MPWs önskemål kommer upphandlingen av den internationella konsulten att följa Sida Procurement Guidelines (SPG) mest för att undvika förseningar i upphandlingen och för att kunna ta del av Sida kompetenser i både upphandlingar och den tekniska och finansiella utvärderingen av internationella konsulter. Sida bedömer att medverkan i TA upphandlingen kommer att ge Sida större insyn som kan leda till bättre upphandlingsresultat och därmed minska riskerna i denna viktiga upphandling samt implementering av projektet. Däremot kommer upphandlingen av byggkontrakten att följa Liberianska upphandlingsregler som bedöms följa internationella upphandlingsregler. Detta kommer att vara ett led i Liberias ägarskap av projektet, trots risken för förseningar i dessa upphandlingar. Denna risk kommer att åtgärdas genom allokering av upphandlingsstöd från TA konsulten.
Projektet bygger på tidigare faser 2009-2016 där projektet rehabiliterade och underhöll 636 km landsbygdsvägar (grus/matarvägar) i Nimba, Lofa och Bong län; utbildade 20 lokala vägentreprenörer; samt förbättrad kapacitet av vägministeriets personal. Tredje fasens förväntade resultat är rehabilitering av 370 km landsbygdsvägar i sydöstra länen Grand Gedeh, Grand Kru, Maryland, och River Gee samt system för underhåll av vägarna som byggts i Nimba, Lofa och Bong och i de sydöstra länen och kapacitetsbyggande av vägentreprenörer, ministeriets personal och system.
Insatsens totala budget är ca 275 miljoner kronor, varav Liberias egen finansiering från den liberianska vägfonden är cirka 78 miljoner kronor.

Objective of major amendment:
The first two phases of Liberian Swedish Feeder Road Project (LSFRP) improved secondary and feeder roads in the central counties of Bong, Lofa and Nimba. The current phase LSPRP3, extended that to roads in the south-east of Liberia (Grand Gedeh, River Gee, Maryland and Grand Kru Counties). Periodic and routine maintenance on those roads improved in the earlier phases was also carried out, largely through strengthening county administrations in support of decentralisation. The region covered has some of the most inaccessible roads and poorest counties in the country.
A pilot was started in April 2021 to upgrade 3 village access tracks in Sanoyea District, Bong County to allow small vehicular access. These tracks will help to enhance the viability of the improved LSFRP roads by enabling low-cost access to a much wider area feeding into these roads. The requested one-year project extension is to continue this work, by expanding the village access track upgrading and providing bicycles and a three-wheeled tractor to each CBO to stimulate basic transport services along the upgraded tracks. The demand for transport is expected to increase so private motorcycles used as taxis will be used, as is common elsewhere in Sub-Saharan Africa.
The overall purpose of the project is to: • Improve small-scale farmers access to markets so encouraging more agricultural production and income. • Facilitate year-round access to and delivery of health, educational and social services. • Create new income earning opportunities for young women and men in rural areas. • Increase the capabilities of local authorities and communities to sustain road maintenance.
The anticipated overall results are: • An improvement in rural livelihoods especially in remote, previously isolated settlements, and • Regular maintenance of feeder roads and tracks.

tag.narrative: 2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

2.a - Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries.

2.a - Öka investeringarna, bland annat genom stärkt internationellt samarbete, i infrastruktur på landsbygden, forsknings- och rådgivningstjänster för jordbruket, teknikutveckling samt genbanker för växter och husdjur i syfte att öka jordbrukets produktionskapacitet i utvecklingsländerna, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna.

9.1 - Bygga ut tillförlitlig, hållbar och motståndskraftig infrastruktur av hög kvalitet, inklusive regional och gränsöverskridande infrastruktur, för att stödja ekonomisk utveckling och människors välbefinnande, med fokus på ekonomiskt överkomlig och rättvis tillgång för alla.

9.1 - Develop quality, reliable, sustainable and resilient infrastructure, including regional and transborder infrastructure, to support economic development and human well-being, with a focus on affordable and equitable access for all.

9.a - Facilitate sustainable and resilient infrastructure development in developing countries through enhanced financial, technological and technical support to African countries, least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States.

9.a - Främja utbyggnad av hållbar och motståndskraftig infrastruktur i utvecklingsländerna genom ökat finansiellt, teknologiskt och tekniskt stöd till afrikanska länder, de minst utvecklade länderna, kustlösa utvecklingsländer och små önationer under utveckling.

title.narrative: Contribution on Amendment of Contribution - LSFRP 3

description.narrative:
Overall the results has been satisfactory and the embassy have been very involved in meetings and several field visits since mid-September 2020. The embassy is expecting continuous progress during the remainder of the project period.
In spite of the COVID-19, productivity of works has increased dramatically in the last year. To end of June 2020 over SEK 79 million worth of road works has been delivered. Up to end of June 2019 only SEK 24 million worth of work had been delivered. Since the project started at the beginning of 2018, productivity on road works has increased from SEK 16M/y over the first 18 months to SEK 55M over the last year which is a 343%.
Logistical challenges remain. Fortunately, MPW provided specific permits for contractors to move staff, equipment and materials during the lockdown period. However, the main road to the south east remains in a deplorable condition, particularly in the rainy season.
Quality of work is also a challenge due to highly dispersed supervision resources. LSFRP3 is working in 7 counties rather than 4 as originally envisaged. However, this is mitigated by working closely with the county authorities and MPW Resident Engineers for those counties. Nevertheless, FCG/MPW team members inspect and certify all work done. Inspections are carried out on a regular basis by senior staff who advise and mentor the junior engineers and contractors.
Another challenge has been the lack of contribution from the Road Fund towards maintenance of LSFRP roads. Originally, $8.7 million was committed, but this has not materialised. The project has mitigated this by funding maintenance from Swedish resources. This has resulted in the total amount available for rehabilitation being reduced and the project being spread over more counties. However, this has created an opportunity to support decentralisation to counties.
DecentralisationThe project is at the forefront of supporting Liberias decentralisation policy. A significant achievement is that the three central counties of Bong, Lofa and Nimba since the beginning of 2020 have been implementing Performance Agreements with MPW for execution of maintenance works in their counties. This work includes full project cycle management of periodic and routine maintenance contracts. Reports from the Resident Engineers as well as evidence during embassy site and county visits suggest that, particularly for the community based organisations (CBOs), this management model is proving to be far more effective than the centralised approach by MPW for the utilisation of Road Fund resources. Nevertheless, there are significant challenges. The Counties have little or no experience in managing such contracts and the various accounting and financial procedures and regulations. Some of the counties are not even aware of their deficiencies in this regard. The FCG/MPW team have to some extent mitigated this challenge with several training programmes and one on one mentoring of the County staff and Resident Engineers. The embassy has also allocated additional resources to increase county training on these issues.
Capacity Building: Considerable capacity has been built in the management of feeder roads contracts of MPW staff through working closely with the implementation consultant FCG/Gopa. This is evidenced by the rapid increase in works productivity mentioned above. Capacity for the same is also being built in the county administrations.
A large number of training activities have been carried out in all seven counties and in Monrovia. However, it has been a challenge to the project to adhere to the formalised training programme originally conceived in the 2018 training plan. The more recent update has been disrupted by COVID-19 where assembly of large groups has not been advisable. The project team have instead focused on delivery of rehabilitation and maintenance work.
Cooperation with GIZ has helped mitigate the overall delivery of training in the sector although this was not included in the original programme. LSFRP3 co-founded and participated in the over site of training of trainers (9) and then a follow up phase of training of road works artisans (50). LSFRP3 have also introduced an internship programme. The first was for plant operators (3) and the second was for engineering graduates (9). The engineering graduates have not only received practical field training but have provided considerable assistance to project site engineers.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
